messages.message:
Not sure if this is the right place to ask but do any of our customers use `context['document_text']` param in UDFs? I understand if the document is too large it can cause errors when passing it in as a payload to AWS. Ideally, I'm thinking of migrating the way users can access it (i.e. `context['document_text']` --> `get_document_text()` where the function will be defined above the UDF and will read it in the from the file system) but this may break any current usages and we may need to include documentation to read the file.

@pauline.comising @Anil @jack.robbins @hannah @andy @Jessica

I don't think we can do anything to break backwards compatibility at this point. We'd need to explore migration options for functions using `context['document_text]`  - which, as you and I talked about with Elan when we were talking about moving system keys into the keys param, would not be very easy.
Can you elaborate on where we've seen these issues and how they come up?

btw we have a ticket (https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-3436) for this issue and pauline discussed a plan (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Pi5Q63IvkVbbLtntBLv3h3QdQaio-cLjcnLqseNZlCI/edit?tab=t.0) to resolve it with @raman.goel

most of the implementation work will have to be on the infra side since the custom function runners on lambda will need to take care of this

to answer your original question, yes multiple customers use `context['document_text']` in UDFs
@Sayan how about for now we leave document_text as is since we have work planned around it
Yeah that makes sense. Thank you!
